reviewText: Twenty years ago, a similar film called Face Off debuted, and while the story seemed ridiculous, somehow it worked. Criminal is in the same boat, as audiences have been kept away by the complicated plot, which also seems to work quite well. The film starts with the brutal murder of a CIA agent, who has a secret vital to national security in his head. Out of desperation, the CIA turns to a doctor and an experimental procedure, which will allow the agents memories to be transferred into someone else's mind. The only problem is that the procedure requires a certain type of mind, the mind of a psychopath. Against his will, Jericho Stewart (Kevin Costner) is transferred to CIA headwaters and given the agents memories, but will he become the good agent and help save the world, or will he return to his murderous ways? Kevin Costner stars and reminds us all of what a terrific actor he truly is. It's hard to remember, considering that for the passed two decades he's done mostly romantic garbage, that you couldn't pay me to sit through. Costner returns to action as if he'd never been gone and does an amazing job playing this deeply conflicted, flawed man. Paired with an all-star cast, that features a ton of cameos, Criminal never slows down and will have you on the edge of your seat the whole time. It's not really the CIA crisis or the science fiction that keeps your interest throughout, it's the conflict growing in Jericho Stewart's brain, as he has essential turned into a person that is both good and evil. Yes, the story is a bit complicated, but it is fairly easy to follow, and Kevin Costner gives his best performance in at least a decade, making Criminal well worth the price of admission.

I actually started watching this movie by mistake, but it turned out to one of the better mistakes that I've made recently.

In Criminal, Kevin Costner (who is barely recognizable in this movie) puts in a moving performance as Jericho, a brain-damaged criminal who turns out to be the perfect test subject for a memory implant procedure. Tommy Lee Jones (who looks like he is around 120 years old in this picture) drifts through the movie as the mad scientist who the CIA pays to conduct some experimental brain surgery. I normally love Tommy Lee Jones, but most of the time in this movie he looks like he is either falling asleep or on his deathbed.

Costner winds-up with a dead CIA agent's (Ryan Reynolds) memories implanted into his skull, which come leaking out as the movie moves along. Gary Oldman puts in a solid performance as Costner's CIA handler and Gal Gadot plays the CIA agent's grieving wife.

The movie starts out looking like a by-the-numbers spy movie, with Reynolds making a brief appearance at the beginning. After a bit of backstory on the main characters the theme switches gears to a high-speed thriller, punctuated by some compelling interaction between Costner and Gadot. I wouldn't quite call this a sci-fi movie, but the whole "brain transfer" thing obviously has some sci-fi elements to it.

As plots go, the movie is pretty average. Bad guy is chased by main character, who himself may or may not be a bad guy. What really gives this film its strength is the great performance by Costner though. He pretty much carries this movie. I'm not normally a huge Costner fan, but he really stepped-up his game for this role. It was a good enough performance that I actually had no idea that Kevin Costner was the main character until I saw the final credits roll. His face and voice are pretty much unrecognizable.

Anyway, it was a fun movie to watch and I really enjoyed it. It's definitely worth your time.

"Criminal" is a 2016 genre-bending mixture of science fiction and action thriller.  An extremely violent convicted criminal receives a brain implant from dead CIA operative Bill Pope (Ryan Reynolds) in a desperate scheme to prevent a nuclear Armageddon.  Kevin Costner provides a haunting performance as Jericho Stewart, a man tortured by memories not his own, alongside the daring doctor (Tommy Lee Jones) who implanted them, the CIA station chief (Gary Oldman) who directed the operation, and Pope's widow (Gal Gadot) who must learn to trust a stranger who knows too much. "Criminal" is a surprisingly effective thriller, in which Jericho's interaction with Pope's former life will lead to a twisting finish.  The movie is recommended as decent entertainment.

Ryan Reynolds is an over billed CIA wuss who gets killed in the first scene. However his mind is the only one that can save the world from Michael Pitt, "The Dutchman" who has that proverbial Internet thing to launch missiles that has become far too cliche in films. Ryan worked for Zorg (Gary Oldman) who doesn't care if he is dead, he is still going to make him do his job. Bring in Dr. Tommy Lee Jones in not his most convincing role (Oldman and Lee seriously needed to swap roles as did Costner and anybody else). It seems our doctor has never heard of Frankenstein as he puts Reynolds memory into Costner sporting a new Mohawk, who is also the world's biggest sociopath. He is in a penitentiary, and not a CEO.

At this point we resort to the standard spy film formula and not so much the Frankenstein formula, although I would have really enjoyed just one "fire bad."

In spite of my review, I did find the film mildly entertaining as I do when people get killed by a tough guy. 3 1/2 stars.

Wha- Kevin Costner and Ryan Reynolds in the same action movie? Sign me up, son. And as a bonus, CRIMINAL injects a whiff of sci-fi into its shoot-'em-up spy premise. Plot opens with a frenetic chase sequence as London-based CIA intelligence officer Bill Pope (Ryan Reynolds) tries his durndest to shake unshakable enemy agents. Pope is not long for this narrative. In London, he gets trapped and tortured and terminated.

Comes the pickle: Pope was the CIA's sole point-of-contact for the Dutchman, "Dutchman" being the cyber codename for notorious hacker Jan Strook (Michael Pitt). At the behest of a crazed anarchist, the Dutchman had commandeered Vigilant Shield, the U.S. military's emergency command & control system, with which the operator can activate any weapons system in the U.S. military arsenal. But when the Dutchman gets cold feet, he offers the program to the CIA, but demanding asylum and $10 million. And there was Pope assigned as liaison.

But with Pope gone and his secrets gone with him, the CIA cannot locate the Dutchman (and the now missing $10 million). What to do? CIA, wrack your brain.

CRIMINAL is stacked with a grip of top-notch performers. Gary Oldman, chewing sceneries as CIA executive Quaker Wells; Tommy Lee Jones as maverick neurosurgeon Dr. Franks. Dr. Franks pioneered the science of transferring memories off a corpse and onto the brain of a living human. CIA guy Quaker Wells jumps at this one last gasp, never mind that it's an experimental program what's still five years away from human trials. What's needed now is a subject. Only one in ten million meets the required criteria.

That rare candidate is cooling his heels in a West Virginia penitentiary. Jerico Stewart (Kevin Costner) is a death row inmate deemed so dangerous his mobility must be impeded by a chain suspended from the ceiling and attached to his neck. His meals are dropped from a chute overhead. Jerico is feral and amoral and utterly uninhibited, courtesy of a frontal lobe that remains in an underdeveloped state. He is a full-on sociopath whose credo goes like this: "You hurt me... I hurt you worse." Except he's ideal for radical surgery and neural stem cell stimulation.

The movie's main thrust of interest revolves around how Jerico copes with a stranger's memories, how he transitions from a criminal who's hostage to his own impulses and who nurses an inability to calculate the consequences of his actions into some new person who is suddenly ordering food in perfect French and frequenting libraries. Jerico's embedded recall guides him to Pope's residence where he meets Pope's wife (Gal Gadot) and young daughter (Lara Decaro). Honestly, Jerico's interplay - and the resulting emotional hits - with the Pope womenfolk is what glued me to the screen. The action thrills are exciting stuff, yeah, but nothing new under the sun. CRIMINAL came before WONDER WOMAN, so there was some interest in checking out Gadot's acting chops here. She's okay. Not bad, but also not earth-shaking. The material she's given, her role of Jillian Pope, doesn't much rise above the typical damsel-in-distress routine.

Ryan Reynolds is terrific, but I expected that. In only his few minutes of screen time, the primary purpose of his character is to make a lasting, sympathetic impression on you and me as it's his memories - and, more importantly, memories of his family - that drive Jerico thru most of the narrative, and you had to connect with that.

Other movies had done it before, spun a tale of the monster who develops a conscience. I like what Kevin Costner does here. He's savage and growly and unpredictable, utterly driven by impulse, and there were many moments in which he chooses to do the wrong thing. Often times he suffers bouts of sensory overload, and whenever that goes down, you'd best duck for cover. It's fascinating watching Jerico war with himself, combative and violent one minute, falling sway to Bill Pope's influence the next. I guess you can stretch that rubber band truly thin and draw a parallel with Pygmalion. Too much? Yeah, okay. Jerico never does become, um, genteel. What he becomes is not as surly.

Pepper in intermittent moments with the deranged baddie, industrialist anarchist Xavier Heimdahl (Jordi Molla), who is so froth-at-the-mouth wackadoodle he makes Jerico seem the paragon of prudence. Frankly, Heimdahl is so diabolical and unapologetically cartoony I came around and began to enjoy the actor's performance. CRIMINAL isn't a top-shelf entertainer. The plot is populated with undeveloped stock figures. I rate it 3.5 stars out of 5. The espionage stuff, the actiony stuff, those were fine but other films had done 'em better. There are three primary hooks to CRIMINAL: the sci-fi conceit of memory implanting; Jerico's arc from remorseless reprobate to remorseless reprobate who registers a connection with his - or, rather, Pope's - leery wife and adorable little daughter. The third hook, of course, is that we get to see Deadpool, Wonder Woman, and Superman's dad sharing the big screen.

As soon as I came across this film on Amazon Prime Video, I knew I had to watch it. Why? I truly like action thriller films that have elements of both science fiction and real life struggles within them. This film fit both of those requirements. Now, I watched the entire film and really enjoyed it. Four main reasons why. First, I thought the film had an intriguing premise. Second, I must say that this film's cast was adept at playing their assigned characters. Third, I usually detest films that have long sequences of bloody action scenes, but this film had a very minimal amount much to my surprise compared to others. Fourth, I thought this film ended on an upbeat note with everything coming full circle for all the characters in the film. Finally, I do see a future where Hollywood's producers and screenwriters produce more of these types of films that make us think about our humanity. This is a must watch film for anyone who thinks about how they got to where they're currently and what the future may hold for them in the future.

Possible spoilers.  This is another one of the high-concept films that was trashed by critics, but features a solid cast and an interesting premise.  So hell, why not check it out.  The film opens with Ryan Reynolds as CIA operative Bill Pope.  Set in London, Pope is trying to elude bad guys in order to make an exchange with a geeky hacker known as The Dutchman (Michael Pitt).  At this point we don't know why but we learn quickly that he is making an exchange of cash and a passport for a flash drive that will prevent the evil-doers from taking control of the Wests nuclear arsenal.

Pope reports to Quaker Wells (an over-the-top, ranting Gary Oldman).  While Pope manages to hide the satchel first, hes captured, tortured and killed by the head terrorist, Xavier Heimdahl (Jordi Molla).  Both Heimdahl and Wells need the satchel and the Dutchmans location for obvious reasons.  Evidently the CIA has been conducting experiments with a Dr. Franks (a miscast Tommy Lee Jones) that allows memories and emotions to be transplanted to another human even if the transplantor is deceased.  So a big whaaat there.

Although Franks hasn't tested this on human subjects, hes ordered to find someone and just do it.  He picks an imprisoned Jericho Stewart (Kevin Costner) who is so violent he has to be chained around the neck and has limited movement.  Evidently his mama dropped him on his head or something when he was a baby and it severely limited his normal human responses.  In essence he has no comprehension of civility.  Hell knock down a granny with no more thought than swatting a mosquito.  After the transfer takes place, hes to be corralled until he can come up with Popes memory, especially of the satchel location.  It doesnt come quickly but some memories do begin to appear, including those of his wife Jill (Gal Gadot) and young daughter.  Naturally Jericho gets loose, so he must negotiate his next moves, complicated by slowly developing concerns and emotions, especially those of Popes family.

While there is much to dismiss as sci-fi silliness, the film has a certain wry humor thanks to Costners performance.  Entertaining at its core.

The Blu ray package comes with a 1080p video resolution and a 2.39:1 aspect ratio.  Whether or not you appreciate the story, the transfer cant be faulted.  The movie looks great on disc with excellent color and great detail.  Facial hair is always a test for detail and Costners stubble is well delineated.  Black levels are fine as well.  The film has a variety of settings ranging from outdoors (beaches look great) to indoor darkness (prison cells) to well-lit interiors and they all look good.  The DTS-HD Master Audio 5.1 track is likewise excellent.  I found this element to be unusually wide-spread throughout the surround speakers and the LFE (.1) output.  Although Im not familiar with the various musicians, the film has a terrific soundtrack as well.  Subtitles include Spanish and English SDH.  Extras consist of 2 featurettes (Criminal Intent and Director Notes), some deleted scenes and a music video featuring Madsoniks Drift and Fall Again, all in HD.

A Sci-Fi thriller set in London -
A anarchist 'Xavier Heimdahi' (Jordi Molia) had persuaded associate and 'hacker'Jan Strook' (The Dutchman)
to create a wormhole-program that would allow access to international codes for the launch of nuclear weapons,
however the 'Dutchman' panics realising how the system could be used and contacts a C.I.A agent based in London
'Bill Pope' (Ryan Reynolds) wanting a safe place to stay, along with a large sum of cash in return for handing the
potentially deadly system over.
'Bill Pope' is the only person that knows where 'The Dutchman' and indeed the money is....on his way to meet up
he is caught by 'Heimdahi's men, though tortured he won't give up 'The Dutchman's' location, which costs him his
life.
The C.I.A headed in London by 'Quaker Wells' (Gary Oldman) have a problem, they have to find 'The Dutchman' before
the system he's developed falls into the hands of 'Xavier'
'Quaker' contacts 'Dr Mahal Franks' (Tommy Lee Jones) who had developed a procedure that could in theory implant
memory patterns from the dead-agent into a recipients brain....though finding a willing recipient is another matter.
However they come up with the idea to pull 'Jericho Stewart' (Kevin Costner) out of his confined cell in the States to
proceed with the plan, 'Jericho' a man with an ultra-violent record, a man with no emotions, a man of no consequence.
After the procedure is performed 'Quaker' is desperate to learn what 'Jericho' was now supposed to know, however
initially it seems that he hasn't the answers they seek.
The situation with the hacker is becoming more desperate, believing the C.I.A has let him down he now plans to sell the
system developed to the Russians (not forgetting 'Xavier' remains a player)
'Jericho' who at first escapes custody is beginning to have very confused visions and thoughts, he is somewhere between
who he really is and the C.I.A agent who's partial memory he now carries.
He will in his state of confusion make contact with 'Bill Pope's' bereaving wife and their daughter and also feel the need
to complete the mission the agent was on.
This will put both his life and the life of 'Bill's' family in danger.
Maybe not enough action for many, i myself enjoyed it and believe this to be one of Kevin Costner's best performances in

Criminal, released April/16 stars,among others,Kevin Costner,Ryan Reynolds,Gary Oldman,Tommy Lee Jones and Scott Adkins. What should have been a powerful film with a powerhouse cast is a total and boring waste of almost two hours of film.
The plot finds Oldman as the head of a CIA unit in London. His operative Reynolds is trying to get a man called the Dutchman to deliver him a bag of cash for his troubles. Mr. D.it seems has secured the launch codes to the world's nuclear arsenals and his hack code is why he is such a high priority. A Spanish nutball also has designs on Mr. D.In fact he wants his former employee back into his heinous fold. Reynolds is caught by the Spaniard and is tortured to death before his CIA buddies can get to him.
Back at CIA HQ Oldman gets into contact with Jones who is a scientist who has experimented with the transference of thought patterns from one life form into another. His only success has been in mice. Now it's showtime,and Oldman wants Reynolds thoughts transferred into another human so they can find the whereabouts of the cash. The human they pick is a totally mind bent mother played by Costner,straight out of prison.
The procedure goes off and Costner feigns any knowledge of new thoughts and feelings on the outside,while inside his head is filled with all sorts of memories from Reynolds. On his way back to prison Costner escapes and he tries to figure out the location of the money for himself.
Costner makes a trip to Reynolds house once,then later comes back to explain the crazy situation to Reynolds wife. She figures the cash must be in the museum where she works. All would seem to be alright if it were not for the fact the the Spaniard nutball has also been tracking Costner along with the CIA.He eventually intervenes threatening to kill Reynolds wife and daughter if he doesn't come up with the dough.
The Spaniard sends his female hench-girl to locate Costner and Mr. D.She shoots Mr. D.while Costner kills her. He retrieves the program from the computer and delivers it to the Spaniard at the airport and saves Reynolds wife and daughter. Oldman is totally beside himself because the program is in the wrong hands. Costner tells him to chill,as Mr. D.reprogrammed the software to cause an explosion with the start of any nearby transmission. And of course the inevitable explosion finds one less nut job in the world.
The film ends as Costner gets one of his wishes and that is to stand on the beach where Reynolds and his wife had their honeymoon. Reynolds wife and daughter join him there courtesy of Oldman, who posits that he may offer him a job.
Olman's charcater in this film is in a perpetual state of anxiety and foaming at the mouth whenever provoked,which doesn't take much. Poor Tommy Lee has absolutely no where to go in the film and  he seems to be almost on the verge of walking out of every scene in embarrassment. Costner has played these strong silent types in films like The Postman and Waterworld. At least in those there was a bit of depth and we had some empathy for his characters. In this film,he is as wooden as a tree stump. I feel the worst for Scott Akins. A great action star who had absolutely zip to do except to stand and looked concerned whenever the director yelled"action".Kind of an oxymoron,wouldn't you say? Lastly,the film as a whole runs FAR too long and after about the first 10-15 minutes leaves you wanting to go away....anywhere but in front of the set. The movie delves into detail after unwanted detail and as a result it's a stop and go ride that is about as appealing as anal surgery. And supposedly half smart people pick a raving criminal psycho to put a man's thoughts into....? Does anyone see some kind of problem with that outcome?The characters in this film didn't think so!
Technically the film is in its w/s a/r of 2:35:1,but there are no extras.
In conclusion save your money for this total borefest. Each character portrayal is like a card board cut out;all look,no depth. The plot is windy and confusing and is far too long. The editor should be strung up and fed to the birds. Not recommended to any one at anytime.

Mixing medical technology with espionage may not be a novel idea but in the hands of writers Douglas Cook and David Weisberg and director Ariel Vromen the marriage produces a nonstop action film that ranks up there with the best of them to appeal to the audience need for grit. The very solid cast makes it happen and keeps our attention from square one.

Bill Pope (Ryan Reynolds) is a CIA agent on a mission in London tracking down a shadowy hacker nicknamed "The Dutchman" (Michael Pitt). When he gets mysteriously ambushed and killed, an experimental procedure performed by Dr. Franks (Tommy Lee Jones) is used to transfer his memories into dangerous ex-convict Jericho Stewart (Kevin Costner). When he wakes up with the CIA agent's memories, Jerichos mission is to find The Dutchman and eliminate him before the hacker launches ICBM's and starts World War III. But complications soon arise and the mission turns personal. Gary Oldman plays Quaker Wells, the man obsessed by his own manipulations to save the world from the enemy  including a mastermind Xavier Heimdahl (Jordi Mollà)  with the help of Jill Pope (Bills widow) played by newcomer Gal Gadot, and Marta Lynch (Alice Eve) et al.

This is a noisy but very fast paced action film with a brain  the script makes sense (memory transplantation as a means of saving the experience of a deceased CIA operative).
